Message.Title: Xbox One will go Viral Next Week
Message.Msg: With E3 convention from June 11-13th, it is bound to get a lot of attention. In addition, the shorts, in their attempt to bash the amazing xbox, sited Xbox as a device that the government could potentially use to spy on civilians through camera and motion sensing. Controversy and innovative technology are primed for a media frenzy. My answer is the spy bashing is TAPE. Msft may suggest that you leave your xbox one on all the time to fully take advantage of smart phone synching, video surveillance into your living room while you are on vacation, and immediate voice command as you walk into the living room. But if you don't want any of it, put a scotch tape over the camera. With that being said, here are some of the projected games with this new innovative Kinect motion sensing technology. 1) Track and field- imagine your avatar running through different sceneries as you jump and dodge over obstacles, and fighting off thugs and animals. 2) Fighting games like "street fighters" and "takken" will be amazing as your avatar jumps, kicks, punches-- mirror imaging to your every motions. Special moves like fireballs and helicopter spins may be acquire by a combination of body motion and hand gestures. 3) Sport games like basketball, football, and soccer can not be any more virtual reality as your avatar moves, dribbles, and kicks to your every move. 4) War and combats? Aren't you tired of using those stoneage controllers that hurt your fingers and give you cramps and your joystick doesn't move the way you want to move. With this motion Kinect, your avatar mimicks your every motions; you can crawl, run, jump, and change direction like real life and blast away oponents with msft guns (you have to expect those are coming). Combating obesity is a multitrillion dollar industry, with consumers are having fun jumping, running, dodging in their living room, I wonder if there will be a need to subscribe to 24-hour Nautilus or use that XP90?

Topic.Title: Xbox One will go Viral Next Week

Message.Msg: With Skype, smart phone synch, internet access, movies, music, and voice command, the Xbox One alone will generate more cash than msft's bread and butter softwares.

Topic.Title: This New Rival Is Coming for Apple and Google

Message.Msg: Not at all. Android already dominates in mobile. The only real contender, iOS, is fading. WP has no chance. W8 is not a factor in mobile, and is not likely to become one. So what is the prospect? When another version of Linux turns up, under the stewardship of the current hardware leader Samsung, there could be a serious contest for dominance between the two versions of Linux.

Message.Title: GETTING BINGED. AS MSFT GOES BINGE ON KRAPPY BING. TRYING TO ADD CLICKS. BY AMBUSH !
Message.Msg: GPOP, developers of the mobile sensation "Draw Something" - for $180 million. After months of losing users that once peaked to 14.5 million players over a year ago, Zynga last week shut its New York-based studio, effectively laying off the OMGPOP team. Industry executives say mobile gamers today are spoiled for choice as the industry has exploded. In 2007, when Apple Inc launched the iPhone, there were but a handful of developers. Today, there are hundreds, whose apps sell across the globe on Apple and Google Inc's Android devices. "You see these rocket ships in the industry that explode on the scene with a casual game that's easy to develop with not much money and they gain users quickly. But users get bored or angry because they can't progress without paying more money," Nexon's Mahoney told Reuters in an interview. Nexon has had some success boosting its mobile portfolio, a likely factor behind revenue growth of 24 percent in 2012 to 108 million yen ($1.1 million). LOOKING FOR ANSWERS To stand out from the crowd, developers big and small are seeking ways to build a sustainable business. EA, as one of the best-funded competitors, is turning to data analytics to keep track of its players' gaming patterns and behavior. Japanese gaming giant DeNA is experimenting with on-the-spot tweaks to its games by employees, who adjust conditions depending on what players do, CEO of DeNA West Clive Downie said. Canadian indie studio Noodlecake, known for games like "Zombie Road Trip", is employing loyalty programs similar to airlines with daily virtual currency rewards for first-time and frequent players. Others resort to tricks like seasonal deals and holiday-themed content to boost their rankings on app-download charts during the crucial holiday period. Up-and-coming GungHo, which has seen its shares rise tenfold since October as investors bet on its ability to rise above the fray with its sole title "Puzzle & Dragons," is turning to costly TV advertising to place i

Topic.Title: Xbox One will go Viral Next Week

Message.Msg: That depends on how many Xbox's they sell, and that depends on how much it costs, and if consumers see the value in it, and that depends on how it is marketed, and marketing has never been Microsoft's strong point. If Microsoft can develop and execute a good marketing strategy, then things will be looking up. The marketing for the Surface has been mixed - some good elements, some weak elements, IMHO. Xbox will be marketed to the home market, a more price sensitive market than business. I expect the initial pricing will be in the high side to make profits from first-users who will pay $ to be "first". I would then expect to see big discounting going into the Christmas buying season.

Topic.Title: This New Rival Is Coming for Apple and Google

Message.Msg: What is the difference between Samsung trying to create an eco-system from scratch using Tizen, and Nokia trying to create an eco-system using Symbian? Symbian was a great system that went nowhere due to the lack of a larger "ecosystem". The battle of mobile is the battle of the eco-systems. Apple thinks they have the best eco-system because they have lots of apps. Apps were cool items for early adapters, but not so much for the average consumer. VALUE will be the driver - with value being the best ratio of performance/functionality, to price. Windows will offer an encompassing ecosystem, and here I don't define ecosystem as the number of apps - an ecosystem is ALL your platforms (PC, laptop, tablet phone, games), and all of your "stuff" (cloud storage, music, teleconferencing, video, work papers, photos, etc etc), having ONE easy to use and understand user interface, with you stuff available wherever you are. No one EXCEPT MICROSOFT is in a position to offer that to the average consumer in the near future. The clincher is Apple and Google have no games to speak of (unless you want to count Angry Birds) - neither have any presence in the living room except via laptop or tablet. It is taking some time for W8 to catch-on, but it will catch-on, and the W8 ecosystem will be everywhere. Samsung is going to try to create an ecosystem from scratch using Tizen. I think they have their work cut out for them.

Topic.Title: Microsoft Now Making Almost As Much as Google When Every Android Phone Sells

Message.Msg: Nice PR fluff, but there is no hard data to back up your claims, only reports from hand picked analysts based on spoon fed numbers. The actual settlement agreements are, of course, secret. There has been no noticeable increase in price for Android devices that would lend credence to those claims. Microsoft has announced plans to restructure itself as a "devices and services company". If Microsoft is going to produce devices, naturally they are going to have to license the necessary patents to do so. Companies such as HTC, Foxconn, LG and Samsung all have extensive patent portfolios of their own related fields, and cross-licensing agreements with each other. They could not function otherwise. Read between the lines: “Hon Hai is the world’s largest contract electronics manufacturer that holds more than 54,000 patents worldwide,” said Samuel #$%$, director of the Intellectual Property Department at Hon Hai. “We recognize and respect the importance of international efforts that seek to protect intellectual property. The licensing agreement with Microsoft represents those efforts and our continued support of international trade agreements that facilitate implementation of effective patent protection.” No big deal.

Topic.Title: Will Conservative News Stations Cover This ?

Message.Msg: By JOSH GERSTEIN | 6/9/13 7:10 AM EDT Updated: 6/9/13 3:30 PM EDT The investigations that seized Associated Press phone records and dug into the email account of a Fox News reporter labeled a co-conspirator are just a warm-up act for what’s coming next. New probes might be uncomfortable politically after the recoil from recent revelations of how far the Justice Department went in hunting leaks — and President Barack Obama says he welcomes the debate that the flurry of new and potentially more significant leaks in recent days have sparked. But revealing the government’s telephone call tracking, surveillance conducted on foreign users of America’s top web companies and a highly-classified order Obama signed authorizing the development of offensive cyber-operations have, according to Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, caused “potentially long-lasting and irreversible harm” to intelligence operations. And they may be far more broad and far reaching in their impact than what was behind the AP’s stories about a terrorism plot busted in Yemen or the information about North Korea’s nuclear program that James Rosen reported for Fox. “I’ve been saying for two weeks that this would be the best time in the world to leak, because no one is going to want to launch a leak investigation, but I was wrong,” said Peter Zeidenberg, a former federal prosecutor who worked on the investigation into the leak of CIA officer Valerie Plame’s identity. “When you look at this pattern of leaks, they don’t have any choice.” “They’ve really got immediate huge, major leaks that sort of put the AP story and the Fox and Rosen things in a comple

Message.Title: TRENDING NOW....HP SICK OF WINTEL
Message.Msg: For decades, PC makers had little choice but to succumb to the Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT ) and Intel (NASDAQ: INTC ) hegemony known as Wintel. The software giant and chip maker both rose to ubiquity together, enjoying the most valuable roles in the segmented PC value chain. The vast majority of computers ran Windows and were powered by Intel processors during the rise of the PC. However, one PC maker has had enough: Hewlett-Packard (NYSE: HPQ ) . HP has been in turmoil for years. Mark Hurd's controversial ouster in 2011 also came at a time when the broader computing industry was at an inflection point. Apple had launched the iPad just a year prior, jump-starting the tablet renaissance. Leo Apotheker's reign didn't last long, and current CEO Meg Whitman's turnaround is starting to take shape. That turnaround is very much hinged on a broader approach than HP has historically implemented, one that acknowledges the shift away from Microsoft and Intel in favor of iOS, Google (NASDAQ: GOOG ) Android, and ARM-based chips. On the last earnings conference call, Whitman made it clear that HP is intent on "using multiple operating systems, multiple architectures, and multiple form factors" going forward. Whereas once HP's PC portfolio were all Windows PCs with Intel inside, HP has now broadened its horizons and is embracing Google's vision of the future. HP released its first Chromebook earlier this year, followed almost immediately by a Slate 7 Android tablet reminiscent of Google's Nexus 7. The Android-powered SlateBook x2 convertible was just announced, which sports an NVIDIA Tegra 4 processor. Google is uprooting many of Microsoft's core businesses, and HP wants in.

Message.Title: Chromebook boots faster than a Windows PC
Message.Msg: My $249 Samsung Google Chromebook cold boots in only 7 seconds. That's 7 seconds from pressing the power button to the login screen. Chrome OS is very fast without all of Microsoft's bloatware to slow it down. That's with a 1.7 GHZ dual core Samsung Exynos ARM processor, 2 GB of RAM, a 16gb SSD and NO WinTel Inside!
